intro: Juncus saximontanus, commonly known as the Sierra junctus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Juncaceae family, characterized by its grass-like appearance and dense clusters of spike-like flowers. This plant typically grows in moist, rocky habitats such as stream banks and mountainous regions. Its leaves are narrow and grass-like, while its flowers are small and often greenish or reddish in color. Juncus saximontanus plays a role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for small invertebrates in its native environment.
